message: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4YBxeDN4tbk just a cool video about how business cards need to be design as the best thing for your company
Holy shit. That video screams "self-absorbed douchebag".  Cards like that go right in to the trash.

Maybe he crossed the line lol, but seriously, most cards people give you are crap that go to trash and say nothing worth on it, something important in the message is sell what you guarantee, that's what is important, not your title

Depends on the purpose for cards.  Handing out a card without speaking to the recipient and giving them a reason to give a crap about you is a waste.  Maybe that's when over-priced; over-designed cards come into play.  But seriously: your card doesn't sell you. You sell you.  The card is just the souvenir,  (And I have to wonder, how is a fancy card any different than a fancy title?  Both are arbitrarily contrived.)
Yeah I meant selling you but not with your card in the first place

I would have to agree with @neurogami.  When you're giving a business card to someone, you need to have sold them on you or your product before you hand it out.  I like those Moo mini cards (http://us.moo.com/products/minicards.html) which only have the space to contain one piece of information, but are colorful enough to pique your interest and make it slightly more memorable than the dozen other cards you got at that day or event

Not a fan of small cards (they get lost easily) but agree with the minimalist aspect.  Brian Shaler, for example, has (or had, at least) cards that said  "Brian Shaler" ; he knows that everything of interest about him can be found by Googling his name.

I prefer sturdy but not heavy stock (too hard to pack many in your wallet or pocket otherwise), no gloss, much white space, so I can use them to write notes on before giving them to people.  I.e., "rubyconf" or "monkeybars guy"or something to help people recall why they have the card at all later on. Or directions someplace, or the name of a book.
@italiano40 that guy was on the MTV show Rob Dyrdek's Fantasy Factory. He invited them down to make him a business card after seeing that video on youtube. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eW0fUs-MHoA
